message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s chronic cough, history of working in a sandblasting factory, and chest X-ray findings suggest Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection, specifically pulmonary TB. The calcified hilar lymph nodes look like an eggshell and are known as the Ghon complex, which is characteristic of primary TB. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and adenocarcinoma of the lung are possible complications of longstanding smoking, which is not mentioned as a part of this patient’s history. Pulmonary embolism is not suggested by the patient’s symptoms or history.

The calcified hilar lymph nodes seen on the chest X-ray suggest old granulomatous disease which can be caused by tuberculosis. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is associated with smoking or long-term exposure to air pollution. Adenocarcinoma of the lung is associated with smoking and exposure to asbestos. Pulmonary embolism is associated with immobility or thrombophilia.
